parameters.definition: Units of imported material to make one dose of medicine A
Units of mRNA to make one dose of medicine A
Units of imported material to make one dose of medicine B
Units of mRNA to make one dose of medicine B
Total units of imported material available
Maximum doses of medicine A that can be made
Number of people treated by one dose of medicine A
Number of people treated by one dose of medicine B

description: A university research lab can make two types of diabetes medicine, medicine A and medicine B. Per dose, medicine A takes \param{MaterialA} units of imported material and \param{MrnaA} units of mRNA to make. Per dose, medicine B takes \param{MaterialB} units of imported material and \param{MrnaB} units of mRNA to take. The lab has available at most \param{TotalMaterial} units of imported material and \param{TotalMrna} units of mRNA. The lab can make at most \param{MaxDosesA} doses of medicine A and the number of doses of medicine B must be larger than the number of doses of medicine A. If one dose of medicine A can treat \param{PeopleA} people and one dose of medicine B can treat \param{PeopleB} people, how many doses of each should be made to maximize the number of people that can be treated?
